intro: Puschkinia parvula, commonly known as the small-flowered scilla, is a bulbous perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of the Middle East and Central Asia. It produces clusters of narrow, grass-like leaves and delicate, bell-shaped flowers in shades of blue, purple, or white. The plant typically blooms in early spring, making it a valuable addition to rock gardens and woodland settings. Its bulbs are relatively easy to cultivate and can naturalize readily in well-drained soils. Puschkinia parvula is also noted for its low maintenance requirements and ability to thrive in partial shade to full sun.
